content.description: No Ardbeg! Monday evening, a mid-July drizzle outside, CSNY set to a hum, clutches of people in the sparse interiors of the whisky bar at the stately ITC Gardenia in the heart of town. And there’s no Ardbeg. “It’s fast-moving,” croons the mannerly steward (a note above the “Woodstock” refrain), and hands over the menu – a tome-sized “dossier”, as they call it here, which you wouldn’t normally need if you knew exactly what you wanted. But there was no Ardbeg. That dossier actually befits its given name, packing in a crash course for whisky noobs, with over a hundred blends (which would say a lot for the bar, if only they weren’t out of Ardbeg), each marked with ratings and notes on nose, palate and finish. The Highlands, for instance, named with such delicate twirls of the tongue as Aberfeldy and Aberlour, the Speysides of Cardhu and Glenlivet (ranging from Rs 475 to Rs 1,500 a pour) fetch Highland Nectar ratings between 84 and 89 out of 100. Also on offer are the Lowlands, the Americans (Jack, Jim or John, if you’ve known them long enough; Rs 375-600), the Canadian and the Irish. A stand-alone list (or chapter, if you like) has Teacher’s, Dewar’s, Cutty Sark, Chivas and Ballantine’s (Rs 325 and above). An epilogue marked “rare” highlights curiosities like the Bruichladdich 40YO (Rs 20,000), although the epic prices to note are among the wines, where deglutitions of the Armand De Brignac (blanc or rosé) can be fetched for, no kidding, Rs 1,58,000 a carafe. A selection of Cohibas and Churchills (Rs 1,400-1,500 a piece, of varying ring gauges and sizes) will have you stepping out to the hotel’s airy Lotus Pavilion to spark a fire. And the bacon wraps of manchego and prunes (Rs 425) from the short eats section are a good way to begin. At some point, however, you find that a dossier of this kind would have to carry embellished descriptions of even the humble Old Monk: “velvet smooth dark rum with a hint of vanilla” (Rs 275 a peg; a full bottle retails for Rs 250 at the local “wine” store). But you don’t come here for Old Monk: it’s the Islay line of single malts that you ought to be paying attention to. That’s where the ratings reach the high-90 levels, especially a certain Ardbeg, with its nose of sweet peat, coal and faint floral notes, laden with hints of pepper and chilli, a mellow palate that gives way to sweeping spices and a long, warming finesse. But Ardbeg we didn’t get. So we looked to its consorts – Bowmore, Caol Ila and the Bunnahabhain, the last of which is what we finally decided upon. Twelve years old and rated 84, the Bunnahabhain, true to the dossier, was “remarkably fresh, a tad sweet, and resonant of sea-air, with a clean nutty-malty sweetness”.- Jignes Shah

Once upon a time, Athena was a good place to assume the manner of a judge on So you Think you can Dance. There were people who could shimmy like pros and made their partners look like they wore really nice shoes to hide their two left feet. There was the group of women who insisted on dancing Bollywood-style to house. There was the circle of friends who enthusiastically pranced around and made everyone else yelp and jump out of their way. There was the couple that was literally joined at the hip and bobbed together from left to right like some strange two-headed organism. Today, the amount paid at the entrance on Fridays and Saturdays ranges from Rs 1,000 for a couple to Rs 1,500 for stags and Rs 500 for women. It’s only partly redeemable, so a little more dough has to be shelled out at the bar for a large drink. That has seen to it that the club isn’t packed to the armpits anymore, but it does have some of the energetic buzz of yore, and the blue and red test tube shooters are still ferried around the large room. Maybe that’s enough for a really quick jig in these times. Debaushree Dutta

“If you are looking for perfect safety, you will do well to sit on a fence and watch the birds; but if you really wish to learn, you must mount a machine and become acquainted with its tricks by actual trial.” This quote by Wilbur Wright is inspiring enough whether one wants to invent a contraption that will change the way the world travels, or venture, rather gingerly, like Mulder and Scully working on an X-file, into a spacecraft-styled pub that has the distinction of being the oldest in Bangalore (prior to becoming “Bangalore’s hi-tech beer club”, it opened as “The Pub” in 1986). Assure the waiter that a “couples table” isn’t required (there is no cordoning off of the section to ensure any privacy or safety anyway). The menu must be applauded for its creatively-named headers, like “liquefied inflammable” and “to achieve zero gravity”. The beer (`70 for a tap), kalmi kabab (`200) and French fries (`60) should now be called for with Mulder-like enthusiasm; with Scully-like scepticism, all three are peered at since the neon light overhead casts an eerie greenish glow on everything, especially the oil seeping from the kalmi kabab. Thankfully, the beer’s fine and it can be chugged to hip-hop numbers like “Where’s the love” and “In da club”, while reading quotes from Wright or Arthur C Clarke on the wall - DD

The first section at Pink Sky Bar is for the loner who wants to nurse his drink and soulfully look into the middle distance, or distractedly flip through a book. This area contains a rag-tag assemblage of 1960s-inspired minimalist furniture against pink-toned walls and dark-wood bookshelves stacked with books on art, architecture, design and photography. Here, you must sip on a red Russian (`250) – a tall glass holding a concoction of vodka, lime wedges and pomegranate seeds. Its zesty citrus flavour marries the sweet-tanginess of pomegranate splendidly and is a perfect accompaniment to aimless scanning through any of the books that line the shelves. The second section is the bar – straight out of Mr Freeze’s hideout in Batman & Robin. It has white textured walls, the only colour relief being the pista-green shirts of the bartenders, and the blue and pink spotlights filter through the various liquor bottles propped up like art on the walls. Leaning on the bar, you can take in large gulps of the whiskey sour (`250), while talking to a friend or a bartender, and pincer a shrimp from the delicious Cajun spicy shrimps (`250). The third section is for the large bunch of friends (or even a cosy twosome, actually, with large sofas softened with pillows of lurid pink and fluorescent orange, and dark-wood separators giving an illusion of privacy that allows for free-flowing conversations). Order a plate of lamb spears (`275), and remember to squeeze generous amounts of lime on the juicy chunks of mutton. The drinks at the lounge can work as pick-up lines as well; if you’re looking to woo her, get a between the sheets (`275) – a heady mix of light rum, brandy, triple sec and lemon juice. And if she wants to say no, there’s maiden’s prayer (`250), a strong cocktail of gin, brandy, triple sec and lemon juice - Joshua Muyiwa

Getting to the heartland of Haryana from Bangalore isn’t as circuitous as you’d imagine. Get to Museum Road off MG Road, stop by the hotel called Museum Inn and take the elevator. Reach the top floor. Up here, bang in the middle of the terrace, two floors above the pub The Tavern Inn, is a crossroad junction. Chandigarh, the sign says, is 108 km to the north, Ludhiana farther up at 306 km, Ambala the other way at 180 km, and Bhatinda to the west at 342 km. Set around this sign are a few tables, a few charpoys on one end, and an open tandoor kitchen. You can watch your tandoor bread order being rolled, flung in the air, twirled and baked as you settle down to enjoy some of the more satisfying north Indian fare this city has to offer – great tandoori chicken, succulent kababs and flaky, delicate rotis – all of which warrant repeated visits

Be sure to wear footwear with non-slip soles when you visit Giridhar Bhagatram’s shop on Commercial Street. The floor has been rendered ghee-slick by the millions of feet bearing vats of gulab jamuns since the store opened to the paying public in 1948. But no one seems to care; they come here not for the ambience but for the golden-brown gulab jamuns bobbing gaily in the warm syrup. According to Bhagatram, whose father started the shop in 1948, they sell 30,000 pieces of gulab jamun in a day. They are always served hot and the massive kadai empties out even before the last piece of sweet reaches room temperature – only to be replenished at lightning speed

Sunday brunches at Max are easily among the best in town. Arathi and Axel Schorlemmer serve up an impressive spread of bratwurst, baked vegetables and even the occasional prawn curry, with a choice of fresh coleslaw, beetroot, carrot, or potato salads. Navigating through the nosh at a languid pace is recommended; give the hefty bratwurst some special attention and remember to leave some space for dessert. Sweet endings include home-style apple strudel, a rustic cheesecake and marble cake. Best days to visit are Wednesday for the cold salad buffet, and Sunday for the hot brunch; it’s á la carte on all other days

The mud cake here was created to bless all chocoholics for their devotion. The cake shell gives up a warm river of chocolate at the slightest nudge, and sharing dessert no longer remains an option. However, if you’re in need of a full meal with filling entrées, order the fish and chips with an extra helping of potatoes and tartar sauce. The generous portion of fillet is crumb-fried perfectly, though a bit under-seasoned, and the potato chips retain form till the end. Or you could try the Thai red curry with steamed rice. The dish is a winner just given the size of its portions; the chunks of chicken are large, and the excellent gravy will put you in a happy mood

This nondescript last stop before the flyover to Mysore (or the first on the way in, depending on where you’re coming from) is a popular hangout for family crowds. Located on the ground floor of Dev’s Paradise Lodge, the cuisines on offer are Chinese and north Indian. The music is all-out Kannada played at a low volume, and some of the tablecloths aren’t quite the cleanest in the world.The chicken sheekh kababs perk right up after a dash of lemon and the delicious mint-and-coriander green chutney. Blended in yoghurt, this accompaniment was made like it usually is up north. The kadai chicken (a dish dominated by large slices of onion) and the dal makhani (made of black urad dal) are both quite spicy. The FEDA – an acronym for the owner’s names, Felix and his wife Ida – also has a branch in Chandra Layout, should your travels take you to that side of town

content.short-description: An offshoot of Odyssey India, the specialty store is home to a variety of “fine writing instruments”. Editions showcases luxury and limited-edition pens from international brands such as Visconti, Franklin Christoph, Kynsey, Curtis and Cleo Skribent

All the kitchen staff here call Kolkata their home, and are rather nostalgic about it, as you’ll find out while you wait for your Bengali meal to be prepared. You can’t go wrong with the simple combination of radhaballavi and aloor dum (combo 2; Rs 40), although it’s not as substantial as other traditional dishes on their menu, such as shorshe mach and mutton chops. Radhaballavis are kachuris stuffed with gram paste – they’re perfect to mop up the thick potato gravy with. A pleasant addition to the tray is a small Styrofoam cup of steaming hot, milky sweet cha – if you must wait for it to cool down, be prepared to contend with layers of cream forming rapidly on top

You can choose from their list of “cocktails” (blended mocktails, really) and smoothie, but you don’t get to pick the fruits that go into the concoctions, even though there’s an actual market stall behind the counter. We tried. Luckily, this didn’t pose a problem for our butter fruit juice (Rs 49; regular size) – its mild, sweet flavour without a hint of pulp could come only from perfectly ripened avocados. With its creamy consistency, the chilled drink is as filling as a milkshake. They also offer sugar free juices and juices made with sweetener

This little tea stall features the usual suspects: Earl Grey, masala chai and lemon tea, but it also has quite a few unusual options. The intriguingly named apple pie flavour is a black tea blended with real apple bits and pieces of cinnamon, and it’s flavoured with natural brown sugar. Amazingly, in the unsteeped leaves they offer up for a sniff at the counter, and in the chilled coral-coloured brew that is handed to you, this combination smells exactly like apple pie. The iced tea (Rs 60) is sweet and fruity, and unlike the ones you get in several food courts, there’s nothing synthetic about this one. For a sharper, more astringent beverage, try the warm berry blossom exotic tea (Rs 25). Made using hibiscus flowers, this strongly flavoured tea looks like red wine in a cup. We think it’s best consumed hot and without any sugar. If you want to brew a favourite at home, they sell 75g packs too (Assam tea Rs 30; jasmine tea Rs 80; berry blossom hibiscus

Try the non-vegetarian bowl at Wok ‘n’ Talk (Rs 135). The big bowl of noodles is prepared on order and served steaming hot. It contains lots of crunchy veggies like babycorn, carrots and cauliflower, and you can specify just how spicy you want it

Sanskriti offers typical UP and Marwari specialties, and they use no onions or garlic in their cooking. The full thali (Rs 119) gets you three phulkas, two sabzis of your choice, a serving of either khichdi or rice, the option of dal or kadi, and it comes with raita, pickle and salad. Try the karela here; bitter gourd might not be everyone’s favourite, but its pungent flavours are a pleasing contrast to the smooth yoghurt tang of both the gatte ki sabzi and kadi. For dessert, pick the freshly prepared moong dal halwa, which is laden with ghee, instead of the gulab jamuns

The signboard proclaims this kitchen specialises in Hyderabadi and Andhra cuisine, but it has appams on the menu, its biryani seems to elicit a lukewarm response amongst Transit regulars, and on the day we visited, the guys behind the counter recommended the chicken Chettinad (Rs 99) over the 65. This turned out to be fortuitous: the thick aromatic gravy dish was swimming with lethal dried red chillies and juicy pieces of chicken, and was redolent of the cumin, ginger and garlic it’s heavily spiced with. It’s best eaten with their buttery soft, speckled maida parota (Rs 20 each). The sweetness of the dough offsets the pungent curry well

content.description: The word “ghanta” may find currency among speakers of Hindustani as a reference to doorbells, the tolls at temples, and factory sirens. It may also, in instances of colourful imprecation, conjure impressions of metaphorical fuses, death knells and eternal damnation. Although, among Bengalis, the term “ghanta” almost always refers to a certain dish that, to indifferent expatriates from the state, or pseudo “probashis” like this reviewer, is usually execrable, even if it happens to command a position of culinary reverence that few other delicacies are accorded in eastern India. The dish in question, referred to as “muri ghanta” in full, consists of a fish head (the “muro”) – larger the better, preferably of a decapitated rohu or katla; agape mouth, eyes intact – typically slathered in turmeric, fried in mustard oil, and served on rice. At Dalma, the restaurant for “exotic east Indian” food in Koramangala (the logo emblazoned outside is in Oriya, not Cyrillic), there’s a “ghanta” on the menu that deals exclusively in tiddly prawn (or “chingri”) brain. The curry (Rs 100) of diced potatoes, mixed veggies, and a biting mustard sauce, mixed with rice, makes for an acrid though relatively enjoyable meal. The main Oriyan offering here is a curry of lentils with veggies, and lumps of pumpkin and papaya, which gives the place its name, and is nothing but a variation of the staple dal. Unlikely as it may seem, some of the finer delights of this cuisine features vegetables – far removed from the “kasha” mutton or hilsa fish curry (Rs 125 each) and mutton kaleji fry (liver, Rs 150) that this region is renowned for. Calls for the specials will unfailingly dish up broad grins from the waiters sputtering “mutton thali” and crab and prawn spreads (all straightforward affairs with dalma and rice; Rs 100-150 a plate). But the way to go is with the pakhala: a flowerpot-sized bowl of fermented rice served with veggies inflected with onions and garlic. Exceptionally light, almost like a broth, it goes well with helpings of nadia pachedi (coconut flakes drowned in yoghurt), and khajuri khata, a sweet-sour chutney of tomatoes and dates (all vegetarian dishes are at about Rs 40 a serving). Our recommendation for afters is the chhena poda, a baked sweet dish of homemade cheese (Rs 30). A word of caution: a full-strength lunch of Oriya proportions is sure to ring the ghanta on any working day - Jaideep Sen

Chalk a block The restaurant’s blackboard menu lists the day’s specials Situated off 100-Foot Road in an unassuming commercial complex that offers a rather banal view of a drain and the Subway opposite, Road Trip is not a place you can ask around for if it’s your first time in the area: you would do better to call the management and ask for precise directions. They will patiently guide you (through several phone calls, as in our case) through the harrowing process of navigating the many cruel twists and turns that the Airport Road flyover tosses up. Once you enter, you will be met with a lone poster of a variety of bikes: that and the logo apart, there’s little that carries forward the Road Trip theme. The menu here is minimalist, so look for the blackboard with the specials. When we visited, they offered an impressive variety of ravioli and gnocchi, as well as that rarely-spotted species, the vichyssoise (a chilled potato and leek soup). We chose the sautéed prawns (Rs 210), which came in a buttery sauce with a strong kick of coriander and received several accolades, as did the wasabi-infused salad that accompanied it. For the main course, we went with spinach and ricotta ravioli (Rs 215) and lamb moussaka (Rs 250). The ravioli can be ordered with a cream-mushroom sauce or a tomato sauce; we asked for the more obviously indulgent variety, and didn’t regret it – the meaty mushrooms are a fine counterpoint to the finely shredded spinach filling. The lamb moussaka was also well-received: it was topped with a greasy layer of melted cheddar, and its tangy, sweet filling was replete with succulent bits of sautéed eggplant. Encouragingly for the calorie-watchers, not everything comes sinfully bedecked in a cream sauce: lighter options include whole wheat pita sandwiches and pizza, as well as a non-trivial salad menu. We tried the pear and walnut salad (Rs 190), which was stellar: crunchy pears with garlicky vinaigrette and generous amounts of grated parmesan = salad WIN. The dessert section also offers some inspiring picks: you’ll find Paris-brest, pavlova, crème brulee and a variety of meringues on the menu. The walnut meringue (Rs 75) is pleasantly crackly and a touch too sweet; thankfully, this is dimmed by the billows of (we’re guessing inadvertently) unsweetened whipped cream it comes with. The apple tarte tatin is not quite the classic dessert of caramelised fruit, but because you can’t go wrong with a buttery, flaky base and huge slices of apple, it goes down well. Road Trip’s interest in keeping you satiated is evidenced in more than their attentive service: if you want something that’s not on their menu, all you have to do is seek, and ye shall receive. As you walk to the facilities, don’t forget to casually peek at their kitchen to take in the heartening spectacle of all your orders being cooked live - Neha Mujumdar

content.short-description: This new restaurant in JP Nagar serves delicacies from Thailand such as banana leaf-wrapped tofu, grilled fish in betel leaves with dried shrimp, lemon, chillies, peanut, ginger and shallot, and isarn laab minced chicken salad served with roasted rice. They also cook up a selection of Thai-influenced Chinese dishes from Bangkok’s China Town, such as kung pao tofu and cumin chicken served in a hot clay pot. Aroy has dishes from Myanmar on the menu too: the classic Ong Noh khao suey, which is noodles with curried chicken broth served with a variety of accompaniments including fried onions, boiled egg, spring onions, fried garlic and lime; as well as lesser-known specialties like vegetable pot stickers and Burmese prawn and okra curry

Waiting to be served at this smoky, dingy two-room restaurant (we use the term in its loosest sense) is as much a pleasure as it is a penance. The biryani is cooked on coals, so if, on the day you are there, the coals don’t light up, you’ll either have to go elsewhere to eat, or wait. And the wait could take more than two hours. Even when all is normal, the atmosphere is hardly one you’d expect at a place where food is worshipped: patrons frequently curse the cook in a Babel of expletives. And the cook curses right back. You have to jostle for space and wiggle through people to get your biryani in a donne (a bowl made of dried banana fibre). When you do get that donne, and a relatively quiet place to eat, the pleasure begins. Because Shivaji believes in slow-cooked food, every morsel of rice retains the flavour of mutton. The meat itself is divine, marinated and cooked so that it crumbles off the bone. There are usually only three items on the menu at Shivaji: fried mutton, fried chicken and the mutton biryani

The omelettes here, served out on the wooden decks at The Egg Factory, are perfect to a slight scrunch in their tomato and chilli fillings. That’s just a comment about the regular omelettes. The masala, three cheese (mozzarella, cheddar and parmesan), broccoli and mushroom options apart, they’ve got variations named Polish (with onions, potatoes and zucchini), Hungarian (with red bell peppers), Irish (with potatoes and chives flavoured with lemon juice) and Spanish (with red kidney beans, potatoes, red peppers). Specials include the akoorie, or classic Parsi scramble. From the desserts section, make sure you sample the regulars’ favourite, caramel custard, or try the new-on-the-menu choco-sin, a dense mousse set on a base of chocolate cake, served with whipped cream

Order the crab masala here – it’s spicy and succulent. Their mutton kozambu, despite being adeptly spiced and well-cooked, presents a challenge when you attempt to separate meat from bone. Since this may not be a convincing enough argument for the resplendence of our neighbouring Dravidian state, ask for the brain fry next – it’s solid in consistency, and therefore more civilised. Most of these items are best consumed with stringy iddiappam, but you can also order soft idlis or khali dosa, which has a slight sting of toddy. At Naachiyar’s, you sit on wooden benches – not necessarily a great thing if, like us, you intend to remain for ages

content.description: "In the imaginations of many people raised in Bangalore, every place worth eating at or even being seen at has to be within a four-kilometre radius from the Mahatma Gandhi statue. Either that or it has to smack of reverse snobbery: ""I drink at Dewar's because it's cheap."" Venturing anywhere beyond these settings would mean the changing of daily itineraries and other such complications which your standard-issue Bangalorean would much rather do without. But then a restaurant like Aroy will spring up in JP Nagar 3rd Phase, eight kilometres from that statue, and entire lives have to be reconfigured. This new restaurant, which offers Thai and samplings of Chinese and Burmese street food cuisine, makes it worth your while to brave a gruelling drive across town for a meal. We started with the banana blossom cakes and Thai pickled cucumbers (Rs 165) which, although fried, were light on the tongue and allowed the delicate taste of the shredded banana flower to emerge. The pandan chicken (Rs 195) effortlessly married the sweet flavour of the screw pine leaves with the smoky flavour of the grilled meat. The dish was good enough to win over a chicken-hating friend. We paused at the salad section, and the Namtok lamb (Rs 165) aptly rewarded our attentions with its citrus tang. For the main course, we tried the Chinese cabbage, shitake and burnt garlic noodles (Rs 175), accompanied by lamb and bitter gourd with black bean (Rs 250), and were thrilled with the combination. The fresh flavours of shitake and pok choy were intact in the noodles, while the initial sourness of the lamb dish gave way to a deliciously bitter and meaty after-taste. We also tried the pineapple fried rice with raisin, beads of water chestnut and nuts (Rs 175), accompanied by Burmese prawn and okra curry (Rs 395). Our worries that the Hawaiian influence would derail the meal were unfounded - the kick of tamarind in the curry reined in the sweetness of the pineapple and raisins. We wrapped up this culinary circus with a Thai dessert staple - water chestnut rubies in coconut and jasmine syrup and shaved ice (Rs 125), a dish that upheld the quality of freshness that had distinguished the rest of the meal. Be an adventurous Bangalorean, abandon the itinerary and indulge yourself. It's cheaper than a flight ticket to Bangkok or Naypyidaw. - Joshua Muyiwa"

"Blue Fin suffers from a serious flaw - for an establishment that models itself after fast food chains, service here is glacial. The counter at which you place your order, the long aluminium-topped table set in the wall and the bright wall-mounted menu with photographs of unreasonably delicious-looking dishes are all reminiscent of places where you'd go to get a quick fix of oily, fried chicken or burgers dripping suspiciously coloured sauce. But on ordering you are likely to be told that it will take 20 minutes to prepare your food, and if your order is substantial the actual time before it is handed to you will probably be closer to half an hour. Yet it isn't slow service that is Blue Fin's undoing. That distinction belongs to their prawn offerings, which comprise a major part of the menu. The people behind Blue Fin seem to have miscalculated a critical factor in planning a seafood café that largely caters to takeaway customers: prawns continue to cook in hot sauces after they've been taken off the flame. This means that a large number of Blue Fin's patrons will have endured the same fate as this reviewer: taking home a packet of Serangoon prawns (with pepper and oyster and soy sauces, Rs 99) or Colaba prawns (with butter garlic sauce, Rs 110) in eager anticipation of a feast ahead, ripping the packet open and emptying the contents into a bowl, then biting into a prawn to discover that its texture can be described most easily by that adjective dreaded by purveyors of prawn preparations the world over - rubbery. All the other prawn dishes ordered (Koh Samui prawns, with honey and chilli sauce, Rs 99; Chowringhee prawns, with mustard sauce, Rs 99) confirmed this diagnosis when they were unwrapped and eaten with their complimentary Kerala parotas (Rs 20 per piece if ordered separately). The quality of the catch didn't impress either; the prawns were thin and, rather than define the dishes, lay defeated in their gravies. The whole fried mackerel (Rs 75), on the other hand, slathered in spices that had seeped through the flesh of the fish, was pronounced ""pleasingly subtle"" and ""surprisingly plump for the season"" by a companion. The crab cutlets (Rs 79), too, were satisfying, the soft brown outer shell breaking apart to reveal an interior of lightly spiced crab mince. The sole beverage on offer is Colber, a ruby-red Indian berry drink, and is recommended. While it may not cut through grease in the way that only cola drinks can, its salty-sweet taste is kinder to the palate, and at Rs 15 a glass, it's also easier on the wallet. - Ajay Krishnan"

"Ayda, it appears, is almost always populated with incredibly beautiful, kohl-eyed women of Persian descent. If these houris, emerging as they do from wisps of shisha smoke, don't catch your fancy, you could, of course, indulge in what you came here for in the first place: food. It's a capital idea to begin with a plate of dande kababs, barbequed mutton ribs served with naan. The kababs are marinated in the woodiness of cinnamon, the bite of nutmeg, the summery wonder of parsley and the zest of lime - each strikes a strident note on your tongue. Such spices ring true in other dishes too - kobideh momtaz, a barbequed mutton mince mixed with Persian herbs and served with ghee and saffron rice, and joojeh halazuni, a rolled chicken fillet marinated in saffron and Persian herbs and served with pickled vegetables. If you are too accustomed to the Indian tradition of consuming breads with gravy, you have no recourse but to improvise: take the barbequed tomato that is infused with the juices of the meat and squash it into your rice, adding a dab of ghee. But whatever you do, do not commit the sin of leaving this place without trying their havich bastani, carrot juice swirled into ice-cream. It's as easy on the tongue as the patrons are on the eye."

"The khaima here is among the best you’ll get in Bangalore – it balances the heat and sweet notes of its spices splendidly and yields to the slightest touch, like a besan ladoo. BG Hotel serves its customers in plates that are divided into neat compartments – two little craters for the gravy, one slightly bigger one for the meat you’ve ordered, chops, khaima, chicken masala, mutton fry and so on, and one large square for the mudde and rice. The mudde here is, again, quite different from others you’ll get in Bangalore. It is far smoother and compressed tightly enough for you to tear bite-sized pieces out of it. "

This restaurant champions a cuisine where the freshness of ingredients is crucial and errors can’t be masked by spices. Harima’s sushi platter is a worthwhile investment: fresh fish on perfectly vinagered rice. The crisp fried soft shell crabs are to kill for. But the best things on the menu are the last: wasabi and green tea ice creams. Order one scoop each to experiment and alternate spoonfuls. One is fire, the other an extinguisher. A great way to spend a special evening.

It is the kadi in the kadi chawal combo that establishes why Khushboo gets crowded at mealtimes: the subliminally spiced curd gravy is marbled with milk fat and chilli powder, and the deep-fried besan pakoris are light and flavourful. Khushboo’s menu features other north Indian specialties such as gatte ki sabji, chuchu bengan and kanji vada, but if you take a cue from the other tables you’ll order the uttam thali. You get a bowl of tomato soup served with croutons (when did that get appropriated as a fail-safe appetiser in Indian restaurants, anyway?), followed by a serving of fluffy dhokla. A vegetable korma makes its appearance, but ignore it in favour of the excellent creamy kaali dal, redolent of cloves and bay leaves. Papad, boondi raita, peas pulao, phulkas, pickle and salad make this quite a substantial meal, with the staff on hand to serve you seconds (or thirds). To end the meal, they bring a kulfi falooda to the table: layered with vermicelli that’s stained pink with rose syrup, the milky dessert is textured with a generous sprinkling of chopped pistachios and almonds.

This unassuming eatery serves wholesome Kashmir Valley cuisine. While you wait for your food to arrive, sip on the kungh lassi. The metallic honey of the kungh (saffron) shines through the creamy lassi. The classic tabaq maaz, slow-cooked and fried lamb ribs, has to be torn off the bone by hand, teeth and brute force to reveal a layer of fat, but eating this kabab is a rewarding process that attests the skills of self-professed carnivores. Next, try the yakhni goshtaba– tender lamb dumplings in fragrant, thin yoghurt gravy, and the kungh cockur curry – chicken that just slides off the bone, cooked in a piquant saffron-based sauce. Both go wonderfully with steamed rice, and you’ll soon realise this is a meal best enjoyed with your hands. Make sure you try the kahwa, traditionally had at the end of dinner. Served steaming hot, with chopped almonds settled at the bottom of the shallow cup, the sweet saffron infusion would make the perfect end to the meal, but you won’t regret ordering the rose-water flavoured phirni as well.

This tapas bar always brims with good intentions and is full of good cheer. The platter of crumb-fried fish fingers makes a happy pairing with the drinks and remains our favourite. You'd do well to ask for the minced lamb here: albondigas con salsa (lamb mince balls in salsa sauce). It's a good break from the fowl and fish and goes well with the excellent whiskey sour. The dessert, a cointreau crème brûlée, keeps up the high standards too.

"One step inside the leafy confines of Halcyon Condominiums confirms they got the name right: it is indeed tranquil here. The best thing about Cilantro, apart from the wonderful service without the five-star prices, is that they let you linger. There’s no rush. After all, they never close. Order the basil-infused fried mozzarella any time you drop in, just to marvel at the sweet-and-sour salsa that spices up the crumb-fried cubes of cheese. If you’re there during meal times, order the Cilantro special sizzler. It has huge quantities of chicken shaslik on rice, topped with spicy barbecue sauce, while the poached red snapper fillet is just as substantial a serving. The fish is subtly flavoured with saffron and flakes perfectly to the fork.

Eating here requires some planning: the restaurant is tucked away on the first floor of a serviced apartment. Bangaloreans who have been to the previous avatar will remember the place for its well-known Parsi favourites. Still on the menu are the chicken farcha (fried chicken), patrani machhi (fish steamed in banana leaf) and dhansak (mutton in a lentil gravy), to be had with cinnamon-flavoured brown rice or rotis. The accompanying kachumbar (chopped onions, tomatoes, green chillies and coriander dressed in lemon juice) is free and offsets the gentle flavours of the dhansak well. Desserts are also made in-house, the winners being the warm creamy lagan nu custard and the malai kulfi.

An open courtyard right in the middle lets you lunch, or dine, in the light of the open skies. They’ve recently renovated, so you can soak up the cheery atmosphere at the even-bigge bar and take your pick from the tapas on offer. The bacon quiche and the beef steak remain eternal favourites. The pièce de résistance, however, are the entrées. Especially the salad of wafer-thin slices of Parma ham and scoops of melon. Owner-chef Manjit Singh will try to convince you that the real stars are his desserts; try a slice of the eggless chocolate cake and you’ll understand what he means. And if you’re there on the weekend, catch live performances with your meal as well.

It helps to be with familiar with the local tongue at a place like Malgudi. For starters, the munakai soup is only lentils and drumsticks cooked with aromatic herbs, a sort of refined sambhar, if you wish, while the attukal and the nandu versions are made with a leg of lamb and crab, respectively. You wouldn’t need a translator to pick out the cashew curry masala (batter-fried with onions) and the lamb pot roast with coconut. The popular non-vegetarian picks include the fish pulimunchi (spicy sear fish curry) and the karimeen pollichathu (pearl spot fish steamed in banana leaf). All of that goes down well with appams and neer dosa, or lemon rice, or you could even ask for a bagala bath (vermicelli curd rice) or stick to the ragi mudde and jolatha rotis (made from maize flour).

Ruh is the latest venture by the same folk who run Chandni Chowk in Koramangala and Heera Panna on Church Street. Here, the shisha fumes (of flavours such as apple, grape and paan masala) swirl into a heady breeze, and your evening is lit up by scented candles aplenty. The chicken in orange- and tequila-sauce and the mushroom paella with walnut pesto are excellent picks, as is the lamb warak inab (vine leaves stuffed with minced lamb served with rice cooked in Arabic spices). But it’s the specials here that you may want to consider – such as the outdoor barbeque, which makes the most of the open ambience and succeeds in exterminating the shisha vapours too. For dessert, our top pick is the gulab jamoon flambéed with rum.

If she could be plated Sue R John would have been the best dish at this Caribbean restaurant: spicy, sweet and full of goodwill, just like the food she cooks up. The juicy pork curry is mind-blowing and is the star of her Sunday brunch. Apart from the curry, the massive buffet spread includes Jamaican jerk chicken, Trinidad juicy beef stew and fish akra (cutlets). Regulars seek out the geera pork – cubes of the fatty meat slathered in Tobago-style cumin-spiked gravy, served with rice, tomato dal and mother-in-law salad. The spicy salad has a liberal supply of green chillies, thus earning its name.

Skip the regular menu and focus on the restaurant’s specialty: the Mongolian barbecue. You take a pick (vegetarian, non vegetarian, seafood), ask for a particular type of noodle and choose a hot bowl of accompaniments to go with it – we like the Asian hot bean bowl with lamb, flat noodles, bean sprouts, pak choi, water chestnuts and shitake mushrooms. You can also try the elephant chilli garlic bowl with seer fish, udon noodles, shredded potatoes and carrots in a surprisingly serious chilli oil-infused pepper sauce. The chef comes out and gets it all together with a deft hand.

The Garden Restaurant at Jayamahal Place is all about location. It is set in the verdant gardens of an erstwhile palace, which now offers its rooms to lodgers. The menu at The Garden Restaurant offers an array of north Indian food. However, the good news is that, it isn’t the typical ‘tandoorikaalidalbutterchicken’ variety. There are a number of unusual dishes to choose from. A must-have is the fish ajwaine tikka: the fish is crispy with ajwaine on the outside and tangy with masala on the succulent inside. The bhuna palak here tastes like butter. Its mouth-watering garlic- and cumin-seasoning is surprisingly delicate. The rahara ghosh, a mix of mutton chunks and mince, is a dish fit for kings, and the chicken biryani is excellent without being too oily. The waiters don’t stand on too much ceremony. They are warm and easy, maybe even a shade shabby. So you don’t have to worry about dressing up for this royal location.

It’s more apt to call this a kitchen for Punjabi cuisine rather than a restaurant. Nayadaur is primarily a takeaway joint, but if you’re hungry enough, and amenable to the idea of dining on the pavement you’ve parked on, they’ll set up a table for you. The food is brought quickly out of the kitchen: their chicken chilli sheekh kabab sizzles with oil, comes chopped up like a sausage, and is served on a stir-fried bed of crisp capsicum, garlic and onions. Both the chatpata paneer tikka masala and the Punjabi chicken masala are fiery and laden with spices. The chef shows a lighter hand with the vegetables – the okra in the bhindi aloo retains its crunch and colour, while the wedges of crumbly potato are lightly seasoned with turmeric and lime. The dishes are best eaten with the lachcha paratha – it’s as big and greasy as the plate it comes on, but it unspools easily. If you need a more delicate counterfoil to the heavy flavours of the dinner, try the pale and paper-thin roomali roti.

At Pizza Stop you won’t find the pepperoni endemic to fast-food chains or the Parma ham of swish Italian restaurants, but neither will you miss them. Here, they stick to what they do best: there are over 15 types of vegetarian wood-fire oven pizzas on the menu, and that’s pretty much it. The Zorba is a good choice, with fresh tomato sauce, mushrooms, garlic and black olives; an extra topping of sundried tomatoes adds a delicious tang to the combination. Also try the Mediterranean – topped with artichokes and oregano, and grated parmesan, which adds sharpness to the bland mozzarella. You can also customise your pizza to make it as “gourmet” as you like with extra toppings such as capers, jalapenos, broccoli and asparagus. The toppings here don’t look sprinkled on like garnish, nor are they leaden weights like with most American versions of the pie. Fresh ingredients and the perfect amounts of stringy cheese on crispy-thin pizza bases make for a light, flavourful meal.

at the Royal Orchid Resort, is more of a lobby bar than the lounge bar it purports to be – to get to it you walk past the reception and turn a corner to find yourself in a brightly lit open area with cushioned cane seating and what sounds like videogame menu music piping through the speakers.The drinks list, though skewed heavily in favour of fruity concoctions, is a promising read – the cocktails are exhorted confidently, among them the my martini (Rs 225), with lemon vodka, cucumber vodka mix, brown sugar, apple juice and fresh grapes, and the passionate lassi (Rs 175), with vodka, passion fruit juice and yoghurt. Encouraged, we decided to put the bartender’s skills to test and ordered the Mumbai martini (Rs 195),a risky-sounding vodka cocktail with curry leaves and crushed ginger, and the watermelon mojito (Rs 195), which we were assured would be served with fresh melon.When it arrived, the martini resembled a cold and watery soup with only a slight kick of vodka, while the promise of fresh fruit in the mojito was unfulfilled – it was made with syrup and mint leaves that weren’t muddled with the mix, rather seeming to have been tossed in after. It took a few sips to get accustomed to the sugary shock that this drink delivered to the brain, but once that was done, it was found to contain a pleasing quantity of rum. We also tried the acapulco (Rs 195), with orange juice, tequila and dark rum, and a daiquiri (Rs 195). While the former was ruled by the cloying taste of orange juice from a carton, the latter was competently mixed, with a pleasing balance of rum and lime. Finding the menu short on bar munchies, we settled on more elaborate fare, starting with the wasabi-grilled prawns (Rs 550) and a salad of glass noodles with raw papaya, broccoli and mushrooms, served with chilli jam (Rs 115). While the prawns were large, deliciously meaty and juicy, we couldn’t taste wasabi in them, although a companion who mopped up the lime marinade with a finger and licked it declared that he did faintly detect the familiar punch to the nasal passage. As for the salad, the noodles formed a tough, chewy nest in which the crunchy, chilli jam-coated sticks of papaya were too sparsely distributed (the mushrooms and broccoli sat to one side of the plate, seeming uninterested in the proceedings).Wondering if perhaps the chef’s expertise lay in other culinary styles, we tried the subz chaat tokri (Rs 105), which the menu described as a mix of saundhe aloo chaat, papri chaat and kachori chaat, but on arrival turned out to be nothing of the sort – it comprised eight soggy puris filled with onion and traces of sprouts, accompanied by a bowl of sweet tamarind chutney. No sign of kachori or papdi or aloo. The bruschetta (Rs 115) with buffalo mozzarella and basil suffered on account of the fact that the entire assemblage of bread and topping had been heated, reducing the tomato and basil to a warm pulpy mush. - Ajay Krishnan

The Corner House chain started in 1982 with the first parlour dishing out the very welcome death by chocolate on Residency Road. Across the road from this heritage site is 77 Degrees East. Here, the music spans genres, going from house to a surprising “Saat Samundar” from Bollywood, and the general look of the lounge makes you contend that it was more suited to a couple of guys looking for cheap booze than a girlfriend-boyfriend-like situation. The drinks are reasonably priced and the bloody Mary (Rs 180) is mixed by a knowledgeable hand. The food scores magnificently on cholesterol-boosting oil and intestine-burning spice, but not on taste. Thankfully, that can always be rectified with a hot chocolate fudge junior at Corner House. - Arati Rao

Snuck in one corner of this luxurious hotel’s lobby, beside a customary handicrafts boutique, there’s a lot that Bling can reflect on in terms of a plan gone wrong. The interiors, for one, seem a result of designers working in disjunction, with black-and-white furniture set against green walls and a ceiling with embedded pink lights. And there isn’t much you can say about the food either. Apart from the seafood platter and tandoori braised ribs, and the clay oven picks of malai til bhuttia (baby corn) and lal mirch paneer tikka (spiced cottage cheese chunks; Rs 350 each), a few insipid creations like the blue cheese and rocket brochettes and calamari fritos (Rs 375 each) litter the fare. Bling’s drinks menu, too, is as wishy-washy as the food, with martinis (all Rs 475) called bond with the best (vodka-based of course, Double O always took his with three measures of Gordon’s and vodka) that’s “shaken, not stirred” and the Q (with blue Curacao and lime juice). There’s a “dirty” version with gin and olive brine, a melonpolitan, one called Florida Keys, with Jack Daniel’s, and an espresso martini with vodka and Baileys Irish cream. The headiest cocktail here is the “kurant affair” of vodka charged with champagne. Beers on offer include Guinness, Becks and Stella Artois (all Rs 375 a pint). There’s awine list, including names from Argentina, Australia, California, Chile, Italy, Portugal, South Africa and France. If you’re a wine connoisseur, the drive to Bling is definitely worth it. - Joyce D’Souza

Make no mistake about it. This one’s a B-A-R, as the neon sign outside says in bright crimson. As you walk up the grimy metal steps to the seating area, you wonder how many people have traversed the same path, only head-first, after a raucous brawl. Once you’re seated, an old Hindi song, a rarity this side of the Vindhyas, reaches your ears and your memory is forced to totter into action to blow the dust off its recesses to find which film it’s from. Best of all, the prices are dirt cheap (which funnily befits the place). You can blink and rub your eyes but the menu clearly states 180 ml of Bacardi will cost Rs 210, which, if you know your alcohol measurements, means you get about three larges, and you wonder if there’s any better kind of math in the world. The food too is B-A-R food, like peanut masala (Rs 25) and pepper chicken (Rs 70),and surprisingly not too bad. Brigade Fuel is worth a visit if you’re a guy who can’t go to Pecos, Le Rock or Guzzler’s Inn for quick fixes towards the end of the month. Brigade Fuel is worth a visit if you’re a woman only if you’re covered from head to toe and with at least a couple of guys for a glug-and-get-the-hell-out routine before you scoot somewhere else that’s nicer and not a B-A-R bar - DD

At Caperberry’s tapas lounge, it’s best to keep intimate conversations to a minimum. This is because other people lounging about here sometimes eavesdrop, especially when your voice gets a tad loud after a few of the cocktails named after the restaurant’s edible emblem. The caperberry (Rs 475) comes in a martini glass, and is a potent shot of Pinky vodka, generously misted at the table with white wine and garnished with the berry – a drink that’s a treat to the nose and the tongue.The lavender and rose notes of the vodka meld well with the slight citrus hint of the wine, and the two stroll happily down the throat.The drink performs splendidly with tabla de tapas marineras-gambas, calamari mejillones de Nueva Zelanda con chile y ajo (in Spanish, that’s a seafood platter with prawns, calamari and New Zealand mussels with chilli and garlic; Rs 675).The chuletas de cordero mentolados al vino tinto (minted lamb chops with red wine; Rs 375) is a perfect antidote to the sharpness of the foam.The tender, well-marinated meat is seared and dressed with the vino, proving that quality meat needs little dressing up.The well-dressed classic mojito (Rs 375) here sure deserves an ovation – the mint leaves are muddled just enough and are so fresh that they still retain a snap - Karuna John

While many other venues in Indira Nagar have already made a mark by hosting live gigs, theatrical productions and even the odd stand-up comedy routine, Cirrus is determined to go the distance as little more than a regular, friendly neighbourhood drinking joint. The big draw here is the “ultimate beer unlimited” Sunday: from 1-4pm, you get to chug as much draught, or as many vodka-based cocktails, as you can (for Rs 400), and they throw in two vegetarian and non-vegetarian starters as well, apart from a bread basket. Off the menu, there’s beer (Rs 70 a tap and Rs 110 a pint; KF draught), while you can dig into the momos (vegetarian Rs 110, chicken Rs 160), or a tandoori platter for Rs 390. The recommends, however, are straight from the in-house brick oven: pizzas at Rs 130 for a base, and Rs 30-40 for toppings. The specialities are their Mangalorean dishes: prawn ghee roast (Rs 285), appams and neer dosa (Rs 30 a plate) with chicken stew (Rs 140), and a portion of Mangalore fish curry (Rs 210) are the best bets on a rainy afternoon. The music here maintains a consistent blare; there’s no point requesting a lowering of the volume, they will refuse, if politely. That’s part of the point at Cirrus too, you’ll realise – this isn’t one of those nightlife entrants begging to be a lounge affair. If you happen to run into Pramod Nanjappa, co-owner and designated “booty hunter” on their Facebook group, he’ll confirm that they’re going all-out for the noisy, thumping, chockfull tag over anything else. Which is exactly what Cirrus has successfully done too; weekday evenings here are packed, service is brisk, the music is audible five floors down over the din of traffic, and the manager will candidly tell you that women can expect some “action in uniform” by 11.30pm - JDS

Located at 3, Cockburn Road, a street name that ranks as one of the most mispronounced in Bangalore, Dewar’s is as curious as it is eternal. It opened for business as a bar in 1933, replacing two other fine establishments – one run by a shaman hawking traditional medicines and, later, a post office. Back in the day, the establishment was run by PD Kanniah Naidu, who counted as the only native allowed into the bar. “Since we were in the Cantonment part of Bangalore, the only customers at the bar were ‘tommies’,” said Varadaraj, Naidu’s grandson and owner of the bar. The booze behind the bar was largely imported (as was the print of the Queen Mum at Balmoral Castle, which still remains behind the bar) – Tuborg’s and Beck’s beer from Germany, Biscuit brandy, vodka from Russia and rum from Jamaica. A “small” glass of beer was sold at three annas and a “large” one at six annas (during British rule and the first decade after independence, 16 annas made up a rupee). Now it’s Rs 50 for a Kingfisher pint, Rs 25 for a large Khoday’s rum. The only “Tommy” you’ll encounter at Dewar’s is the mangy stray that hangs out outside the bar, and replacing the British soldiers and bureaucrats inside is a crowd that is as varied as it is colourful. On any given day, Dewar’s is home to real estate mavens, members of the Bullet Club of Bangalore, students and professors from the Indian Institute of Science and the local drunk who insists on getting lathered while on his feet, until they will no longer hold him up - Jaideep VG

On the curving far right corner of the not-so-large interiors at Firangi Paani (literally in Hindi: westernised water) is perhaps the only pub wall in town depicting an entire scene straight out of a Charles Dickens narrative, right next to a wall-sized Toulouse-Lautrec recreation. That semi-hideous mural apart, the décor speaks of timidly aligned First War of Indian Independence-era muskets on the wall and random anonymous portrait prints of unnamed white women.A couple of polished barrels down the narrow middle make for a reasonable Anglo-Saxon tavern-like feel of stand-around guzzling, or you could sidle up along the bar counter. The far right corner is clearly too cramped. The evident extra-wax-and-varnish job belies Firangi Paani’s lame shot at a classy affair, though the service is comfortingly Bangalore and unobtrusively laidback; the bar hands may feign initial reluctance, but will soon enough give in to slightly persistent coaxing to serve up off-menu requests with a smile. On the counter, the barman’s babushka shooters are the biggest attraction, especially the flamer (Rs 500), a towering martini glass inferno of rum for you to sip with straws. The Firangi Paani cocktail stirs up cognac and sparkling wine with a dash of Angostura bitters (Rs 450), while the veg-platters make for good starters. Sunday nights are for karaoke, and the music devotedly flips between Bryan Adams and Scorpions, or Pink Floyd sing-alongs. The downside: too little legroom inside - Jaideep Sen

Ever wondered how many Bhutanese people there are in Bangalore? How about Tibetans who’ve forsaken some of their dim sum for dosas? Thai people who only read about their country in the back section of a newspaper? Or Africans who reminisce about home through Travel & Living? These questions of census may be answered at Fusion Lounge. With uniquely themed nights centred on hip-hop sprinkled with music from various countries, the club is a melting pot of cultures. As interesting as one’s fellow clubbers are the interiors of the place. The crimson lighting speckled with laser lights from the dance floor and low white couches that slither along the wall set the tone for a very different kind of night. The Rs 300 cover charge gets redeemed at the bar with two plastic glasses of just-about-OK beer. They also have Indian and Scotch whiskeys, rum, vodka and cocktails on the menu. To experience all of this, though, may be a tad difficult for the average Bangalorean. The club’s management seems to be picky about the local crowd they let in and stags don’t have any chance at all. Now that’s international relations at its best - AR

As the mercury plunges during the monsoon, exponents of whisky can attain warmth with the corporate crowd that heads to H3O, the lounge bar on the third floor of Sree Nandhana Palace, after working hours.To start with, the blue-and-silver colour scheme is quite palliative to the eyes. Next, the prices permit copious amounts of fluids to be imbibed: a small Signature whiskey is for Rs 85, a mug of beer is for Rs 70, and a pitcher for Rs 325. And the service is extremely cordial,beginning with the friendly darbaan, replete in a gold-and-red ensemble, at the ground-floor entrance. But there is a bitter side to the medicine. The mojito (Rs 200) is garnished with an entire lemon, skinned harshly like a summer haircut and then wedged unhappily on the rim of the glass. Once this garishness is disposed of, the drink may still taste like lemonade with a shot of rum. Tandoori prawns (Rs 195) are a good pick - AR

entry.name: JP Balimo Food Lounge & Deck Bar

version.name: JP Balimo Food Lounge & Deck Bar

content.description: While Malleswaram abounds in institutions that feed the mind – Seva Sadan and the Indian Institute of Science, to name two – when it comes to offering a similar degree of sophistication for those in need of a drink, the area is found woefully wanting. It appears JP Balimo, with its Zen-inspired tribute to the Buddha, babbling fountains and bamboo-laden walls,is looking to fix the problem that has troubled this neighbourhood for years. Located on the fifth floor, the nightclub comes complete with a balcony overlooking all of Malleswaram – the jostle of Sampige Road, the whirl of night-time shoppers and the shrill cries of flower vendors. Though the balcony isn’t all that large, in keeping things small, they’ve achieved intimacy. However, while on the surface of it JP Balimo looks like it has received booster doses of sophistication and romance, when it comes to actually drinking in the nightclub, things rapidly begin to head south. For one, the waiters here, albeit courteous, are rather slow to respond to pretty much anything you say. And then there is the small matter of the drinks menu: while it appears extensive, and cheap, you’ll discover soon enough that the prices belie the truth. The Aphrodite Greek goddess (Rs 250), a jealous Joe (Rs 250) and a berrytini (Rs 200) might seem downright cut-rate, but when you see the shot glasses they are served in, you’ll realise you’re paying quite a bit. Kankshi Mehta

In a world of squalid, disreputable and fly-blown establishments, this is as seedy, louche and fly-by-night as it gets.Don’t, even for a moment, consider stepping out to the narrow balcony looking over the market road in the hope, perhaps, of breathing in some deserved fresh air: there’s a men’s commode fixed on one end, with no door. The eats, whipped up over a gas stove that you can see at one end of a corridor, range from salted and masala peanuts to fish fry, egg burji, potato chilli and chicken 65 (all Rs 5-Rs 35). The official hour of closure is 11pm, but that’s only for the record; don’t bother asking. Well past midnight – and well wary of cops, for sure – the thing to do to get some “late night” booze is to tip-toe along the shadows up to this bar and rap lightly on the shut wooden planks. If you’re lucky, a voice will respond, “Yen beku? [What do you want?]”, as politely as you can ever expect in these parts, before stating a price, extending a palm to collect the amount and passing on the goods through a crack. Be warned, however: if the ominous-sounding “Yen beku?” comes from somewhere behind you, there’s no point attempting a sprint. Pleading for a lenient reprimand ought to suffice - JS

Going anywhere with a large group in this city is a taxing-enough exercise in logistics – but when said group also happens to be related to each other and enjoys their tipple, it can wear tempers (and wallets) thin. They call Oko a pan-Asian restaurant, but, by the looks of things, fine dining is the last thing on anyone’s mind once they step into the bar or the open-air lounge. Especially when the outdoor area holds a live grill and a teppanyaki bar, and, with golf greens on one side and the city’s skyline on the other, Oko’s lounge affords a near-360-degree eyeful that’s hard to beat. After taking in those 360 degrees and the lengthy selection of alcohol, call for the drinks: Tiger (Rs 200 for 330 ml), Kingfisher (Rs 200) and Foster’s (Rs 200) are available in large quantities, and the martinis are well-mad and served with a bowlful of speared olives on ice. The Oko special set, at Rs 2,000 for 15 bite-sized pieces of eel, tuna and salmon, definitely falls into the extravagance category, but it’s apparently judged a bargain to keep the peace, especially considering the many opinions at the table. Better than the sushi and sashimi morsels are the Canadian scallops (Rs 775) and Teriyaki steak (Rs 625) at the teppanyaki counter which definitely get tongues wagging. And nearly licking the plates clean - AG

address.street: 110, First Floor, 2nd cross, 4th main, HAL 3rd stage
110, First Floor, 2nd cross, 4th main, HAL 3rd stage

content.description: B-52’s groovy, loopy blue sign quite satisfactorily performs the function of a lighthouse on 100-Foot Road in Koramangala – if you drive up from Indira Nagar, it isn’t at all hard to spot this beacon from the Ring Road. Drawing its design cues from every neon-drenched Austin Powers movie, B-52 suggests (at least going by its sign) that inside, you will encounter an explosion of psychedelia. That, however, is far from the case: the black windowless L-shaped room is filled with expansive black leather couches, barstools and pouffes as a nod to modernist minimalism; there’s none of the cotton-candy extravagance of ’60s pop culture. But just when you dismiss the sign outside as an anomaly, you’re confronted by the bar – it is bathed in electric blue light – and the fiery-orange U-shaped tables that you stand at. B-52, it turns out, is an amalgam of two distinct styles, a plangent, two-toned message to Bangalore’s drinkers. The menu contains a wealth of alcohol. The G-spot (`250) – a mix of gin, lime juice, Tabasco, lemonade and fiery green chilli – explodes on your tongue like a cave buster. For a delightful counterpoint, try Boom (`200) which is a mix of apple, chillies and vodka – sweet at first and spicy later. To bring temperatures down to manageable levels, call for the passion cooler (`150), a combination of juices of passion fruit, orange and mango. To attend to your stomachs, try the B-52 platter for two (`250). It arrives stacked with chicken wings, potato wedges, crumb-fried mushrooms and batter-fried prawns. You could choose to remain faithful to your cerveza by calling for the cheese tostadas (`150) – a fried tortilla topped with cottage cheese morsels - Kankshi Mehta

From a distance, this roadside stretch of Madiwala, directly opposite a restaurant called “The Little Libra”, resembles a display rack at a mall. The offices, shops and business complexes are tightly packed in, with signage and display boards crammed next to each other, like they were inviting you to reach out, pick what you want, and drop it into your shopping cart, before moving on. The boards spell out brightly painted names such as “Al Hind”, “Geepee”, “Jabbar”, “Kaleshwari” and “Yesbee”, and you realise they’re all ticket sales counters for inter-state bus services. Somewhere in the middle of all these boards, you’ll find one that says, “Balaji”. This is perhaps the only chamber in the hive-like complex that doesn’t deal in travels. You’ll find the little porch in front of Balaji packed with travellers lugging bags, suitcases and other travel accessories too, and, if you look closely, every one of them hanging about this entrance will have pet bottles in their hands. But that’s because Balaji serves as the dive for that one last drink (or two) before you hit the road from here – safely, too, as you wouldn’t expect to be driving out. And also because they encourage you to get a “mix”, or mix your drink (standard rates apply for the booze) in pet bottles of aerated drinks, making it easier to carry around, rather than get measures poured out. The few people without bags at the counter, downing measures out of plastic glasses, aren’t travelling light; they’re going nowhere - Joyce D’ Souza

If the dizzying elevator ride up 13 floors hasn’t already thrown you slightly off balance, the drinks menu at 13th Floor will. The cocktails here are organised into various categories, and the “short and potent” section harbours some interesting-looking picks: among others, you’ll find such weapons of destructions as the Uzi, Peacemaker Colt, Tommy Gun and the avowedly patriotic Brahmos (all `300) vying for your attention. Of these, the Brahmos – the Indian cruise missile it is named after is a portmanteau word that combines “Brahmaputra” and “Moskva” – is deserving of its own slot on the Scoville scale: the amount of paprika in this tequila drink will lay you low. The Tommy Gun is a mellow, pleasant concoction, elaborately garnished and sweetened with fruit juice. If you’re not in the mood to experiment, head to sections titled “the usual suspects” and “most wanted”. Pick the strawberry margarita (`375) for some fruity, salty goodness, or, if you’re the designated driver, nurse a Virgin Mary (`185). To accompany this swilling, try the Thai sweet corn cakes (`225): the deep-fried cakes come with a deliciously sweet chilli sauce. For a lighter choice, try the Mediterranean chicken salad (`210). At 13th Floor, you’ll find the music tends towards cheesy ’80s staples of the Bryan Adams variety; it’s only once in a while that a song worthy of a jig will sneak in. But then you don’t come here for the music, or even the food and drink: you come here for the kind of tranquil view of Bangalore you gain only when seated overlooking the city. The outdoor section is almost always densely populated, while the indoor section is near-empty, barring the occasional odd pair that wants to (gasp) converse and not take in the views - Neha Mujumdar

Snuck in one corner of this luxurious hotel’s lobby, Bling has black and white furniture set against green walls and a ceiling with embedded pink lights. Apart from the seafood platter and tandoori braised ribs, and the clay oven picks of malai til bhuttia (baby corn) and lal mirch paneer tikka (spiced cottage cheese chunks; `350 each), creations like the blue cheese and rocket brochettes and calamari fritos (`375 each) litter the fare. Bling’s drinks menu has martinis (`475) called bond with the best (vodka-based, of course, Double O always took his with three measures of Gordon’s and vodka) that’s “shaken not stirred”. There’s a “dirty” version with gin and olive brine, a melonpolitan, one called Florida Keys with Jack Daniel’s, and an espresso martini with vodka and Baileys Irish cream. The headiest cocktail here is the “kurant affair” of vodka charged with champagne. Beers on offer include Guinness, Becks and Stella Artois (all `375 a pint). There’s an even wine list, including names from Argentina, Australia, California, Chile, Italy, Portugal, South Africa and France. If you’re a wine connoisseur, the drive to Bling is definitely worth it - JDS

Blue is a primary colour and as African-American musicians who trace their roots to the Mississippi Delta have it, is often associated with the human emotion of sadness. Tantra is a concept loosely described as the ritualistic use of the mundane to become one with the supra-mundane. For all women looking to drink, Blue Tantra promises just the perfect UV-lit ambience. For four days every week, Blue Tantra is Bangalore’s only exclusive ladies’ lounge – the few men you’ll see there are the waiters and a distinctly delighted DJ. On Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, however, the good people who run this fine establishment on Outer Ring Road in Belandur briefly relent, and the ladies are allowed to bring their boy toys. No single man will ever see the inside of this club. That’s the assurance. Blue Tantra occupies the curious middle earth between a dance bar (lurid images of sexy women diving into wine glasses from bottles are on most walls) and a spaceship readying for takeoff. Blue Tantra’s staff will strongly recommend you show up there during happy hours (12-8pm every day) - Darshan Manakkal

It’s hard to get lost when you’re the only two people in the room. But at the I-Bar, the crowd of chairs, stools, sofas, booths makes getting lost, or perhaps a game of sozzled hide-and-seek, easy. Like the living room in a stately manor, it’s been carefully peopled with pieces of furniture that make you feel you’re among friends even when you’re not. With wooden screens that reveal only so much, filigreed brass lamps overhead that ration the light let out and set off strange and wonderful shadows on faces; and pillars that, instead of being awkward, conveniently allow for privacy, the décor is an exercise in the art of intimacy. Steer yourselves to the cosy red velvet booth – perfect for a twosome – and thud down on plump cushions. This is the kind of place that offers cocktails with “saffron-infused vodka” and concoctions of tamarind and gin, apart from staples including Kingfisher beer (`250 a pint). The “dual jewel” (`450) – a spicy cocktail of whisky, grenadine, guava juice, mint and chilli – is a real find. The grilled cumin chicken with chermoulah (`375), an Arabic salsa, will allay hunger pangs with panache. The conversation, as it often does at the end of a long day, might peter out, but this is a place where silences can be comfortable. It’s nice to just drink in all the sensory information: the tastes, the smells, the sights and sounds. There’s certainly enough for all the senses here - Akhila Seetharaman

The fourth avatar of the Pecos franchise (we never in our wildest dreams thought that venerable institution would do anything as capitalist as create a franchise) rests way out on New BEL Road. There was, of course, the stream of the river Rio Grande that first gave Pecos its name and brought along with it the trump chow of tacos and chilli pork, watered-down beer that inexplicably conducts a true-hearted following and the surest play- list of rock, blues and jazz music around. While the two other flanks, Mojo and Stones, presented much the same eats, brew and music, not to forget the decor of tributes to music legends, to fortify a formidable network. But now, there’s no Pecos triangle to speak of anymore: instead, you’re looking at a rhomboid. There isn’t much different at this new Pecos – you walk into the familiar arrangement of a dimly lit room besieged by posters of Led Zeppelin, Queen, Bob Marley, The Rolling Stones and murals of Bob Dylan and John Lennon, among others, and wait for the beer that Bangalore has so come to cherish. There is no R&B to speak of. The coat of paint on the walls – a delicate shade of purple – will seem too fresh and misleading for Pecos partisans. Pitchers of Kingfisher beer (`233), which is the only alcoholic beverage they serve, and plates of zesty peanut masala (`45) are the essential salutations to exchange with the waiter. You may experiment with the comfortingly chewy garlic mutton (`140), or the golden potato fry (`80) - KM

Strawberry Moon is a cosy room with large portraits of musical colossuses such as BB King and Miles Davis. If you are here to canoodle with a partner, you can head over to the dimly lit corner area, where spacious sofas are located. If you are here to impress your companion with your knowledge of jazz musicians, start by flipping through the menu and bemoaning the many errors, pointing out, for instance, that the man in the photograph titled “John Coltrane” is actually Ron Carter (that Carter is pictured with a double-bass and not a saxophone doesn’t appear to have sufficed as evidence for the people that constructed the menu). If that does not sufficiently awe your company, walk up to the large Harlem Jazz portrait and spout obscure trivia about Dizzy Gillespie, Count Basie and Coleman Hawkins, while regularly crinkling your nose at the pop music playing – Sue Thompson in the place of Charles Thompson, if you will. They have six kinds of beer (Stella Artois, Beck’s, Leffe, Foster’s, Kingfisher and Corona (`100-`225)). The cocktails are standard fare and come at `300; the Long Island iced tea and the sex on the beach go down well, though the first is stronger than one might be accustomed to. One pick here that catches the eye is a concoction called hot lips (vodka, lime juice and the intriguing promise of “Moon special spices”). It is packed with ginger slices, and a plump chilli decorates the surface, its seeds floating about ominously. However, the salt-rimmed glass and copious amounts of sugar do much to dim all this heat, and you are left with merely salty lips. The complementary nibbles (salted peanuts and garlicky chips) are accompaniments satisfactory enough to delay the order of more substantial fare. And just as well: the uninspiring selection of bar snacks (listed perfunctorily at the end) and a rubbery paneer tikka (`120) do not bode well for the establishment’s culinary expertise. Head to Strawberry Moon for a quiet evening with friends, free munchies and alcohol; do not head here expecting any strains of Grover Washington Jr’s album that gives this place its name - NM

It’ll probably take you a while to find The Mark Boulevard Hotel where the Checkered Bar is located. Here’s how you get there: make a left off Old Airport Road towards ITPL, go down the road till you reach the BWSSB water tank and make a right at the Advaith Hyundai showroom. EPIP Zone is a few hundred metres to your right. The Checkered Bar is actually quite small. The black and white square tiles that lend this place its name support zebra-striped and maroon velvet sofas. There are several plasma screens TVs here to occupy yourself with as you chug KF (`125 each). The menu bears the names of some rather interesting-sounding cocktails. Try the back, sack and crack (`350) – white rum, dark rum, blue curaçao, mint and lemonade, and follow this up with the cape samurai (`400) – vodka, lime, rose syrup and ginger. The former is well balanced and refreshing. The cape samurai appears interesting, but the ginger in it isn’t for everyone. You could stick with the straight and narrow when it comes to food and order kalmi kabab (`175) and the tandoori veg platter (`275). The portions are large. The kabab is moist and fresh, and the tandoori veg platter comes stacked with paneer, mushrooms, potatoes and peppers, all adequately done - KM

Admittedly, the name “Luscious” doesn’t immediately invoke images of a watering hole, being rather more suited to a luxurious spa or, perhaps, an over-groomed, over-privileged poodle.Nevertheless it’s the name that the folks at the St Mark’s Hotel have chosen for their newly redone bar which, in its previous avatar, was named Phoenix and sported an Egyptian theme.When we walked in, much of the hotel was swathed in white cloth, and the strong smell of fresh paint assailed our nostrils. This, we realised, was not part of the ambient design, but was merely evidence of the hotel’s ongoing renovation. Walking up to the bar, situated on the first floor, we found that there were still some remnants of the Egyptian era gone by in the form of dim blue lights and otherworldly music. The bar itself is cosy, with only eight tables, and the menu mirrors this succinctness, offering only the safest, most popular choices of alcohol. For beer, the options are Carlsberg, Heineken and Kingfisher (all `175 for 330ml). From the short list of cocktails, we chose the between the sheets (`250) and the Long Island iced tea (`250). The first, despite its risqué title, did not deliver the thrusts of citrus flavor we were expecting, although the generous doses of brandy and rum ensured we were left light-headed. The Long Island iced tea arrived with garnish missing and was further proof of the bartender’s liberal hand with the alcohol. We were given a polite portion of complimentary eats that didn’t quite qualify as munchies: freshly popped popcorn and what appeared to be mini-tartlets of some sort (circular slices of bread topped with mushrooms and cheese). Compelled to seek out more substantial fare, we settled for khajur mutter ka chakna (`182), whose location in the vegetarian section of the menu reassured us that it had little in common with the Hyderabadi stew of goat digestive parts (also called chakna). The dish turned out to comprise tasty samosa-like nuggets with crisp crusts and mildly sweet filling. The menu cajoled us to “make a meal” while picking entrées. Swayed, we chose the tenderloin steak (`372) and roasted vegetables fricassee with almond pilaf (`286). The steak arrived drenched in a bright sauce chaperoned by numerous steamed vegetables, but did not measure up to all this fanfare: we did request that the meat be well done, but its texture had crossed over into unassailably tough territory and required significant jaw power to tame. On the other hand, the fricassee posed no such challenge to our abilities: the chunks of zucchini and mushroom were roasted to perfection and went down perfectly with the almond-studded rice. Suitably sated, we traipsed out into the rain. If you’re adventurous at heart, you would do well to give Luscious a miss. Probably the only surprise here is in the “health drinks” section, which offers righteous concoctions such as watermelon-apple-ginger and mint-honey-lime (all `125) - Neha Mujumdar

Saucy name notwithstanding, there’s little about Don’t Tell Mama that offends. We stepped out of the lift on the fifth floor of the Elite Royale hotel and made our way into a pleasantly lit gazebo whose roof appeared to be propped up by faux coconut tree trunks. It was only after we’d made ourselves comfortable here and undertook our first restroom run later in the evening that we discovered our other seating option – an airy and romantic deck with a view that is surprisingly panoramic, even if the vista on offer is that of HSR Layout’s rooftops. Our waiter for the evening was a friendly and enthusiastic chap, though our questions about cocktail ingredients quite threw him off. Unfazed, he told us to sit back and let him decide what we were having. We obeyed and were aptly rewarded. The first drinks to arrive at the table were an un-christened pink gin concoction with cranberry juice and cream (`300) and a caiprioska (`275). Worried by the former’s colour, we sipped warily,but swallowed delightedly. Its bubblegummy flavor coupled with a warm heart of gin made for a drink that compensated for its lack for subtlety by being unarguably delicious. As for the latter cocktail, we inserted a straw between the ice crystals that floated on its surface, sipped, and were delivered a chilled minty brew with an edge of citrus and just the perfect quantity of sugar to calm the palate before the next sip. Impressed, we merely glanced over the hookah menu (`200, available in fruit flavours and with alcohol and Red Bull bases) before moving on to the next round of drinks.The bloody Mary (`275) that arrived soon was another triumph – just spicy enough to leave our lips tingling but not have us fanning our tongues. Only the pineapple sour (`275) was something of a bum note – too sweet and syrupy, with only the faintest hint of whiskey, but by then we were in too pleasant a mood to complain. And we weren’t alone – around us was the distinct gathering buzz of a crowd having a good time.DTM wisely and effectively keeps its food options simple. The tandoori aloo (`135) was a winner, the shell of each baby potato blackened to a delicious crisp, while inside, the delicate sour flavour, too often missing in potato dishes, was intact. The murgh malai kabab (`150) and the mutton chops (`175) were equally successful exercises in grilled simplicity, the rich marinades pairing perfectly with the juicy slivers of meat. If you’re taken care of as well at DTM as we were, you too might leave smiling appreciatively at the aerobic exertions of patrons who have taken to the dance floor, your feet involuntarily tapping along to a song despite its grating chorus of “Ahu ahu ahu” - Ajay Krishnan
