content.description: Milestone is organising a special programme for differently-abled children with a focus on self-help skills

The interiors of Crowne Plaza’s Italian restaurant Aloro don’t offer the intimate, fine-dining feel that its menu tries to uphold – it’s an extension of the main lobby, and it isn’t exactly a separate entity from the hotel’s bar, Connexions. That’s why, instead of a Chopin ballade, your meal is accompanied by an electronica soundtrack. They do a well-balanced dirty martini (`395), gin stirred with vermouth and olive brine. The complimentary bread basket contains fair pickings for those who like crunchy parcels as well as those who prefer them soft and buttery, but the tomato and bell pepper dips it comes with are uninspired purées – the two taste pretty much the same. Happily, the signature appetiser, the Parmesan trilogy (`425), cheese served in three innovative ways, elevates the standards of the place far above those set by the insipid dips. The dish is constructed thus: crunchy caramelised onion marmalade lies in warm, melted Parmesan cream sauce that’s garnished with truffle oil. Atop this, sits a scoop of Parmesan ice cream speckled with Italian black truffle. It’s garnished with flakes of the sharp, aged cheese, which make every bite an exciting contrast of textures, flavours and temperature. There’s a selection of homemade pasta and wood-fire oven pizza on the menu, but we couldn’t look past the risotto di mare (`795), served with flaky pan-seared scallops. It’s made with another exotic ingredient: squid ink, so we expected the dish to be its trademark saturated black. The Arborio rice turned out to be a creamy, bland saffron. Streaks of salty ink do dramatically darken the plate and the fork but their contribution to the risotto’s flavour is muted. The pan-fried di filetto di maiale Italiano (`695) or pork fillet, comes interspersed with thin slices of tart apple and is served with an excellent brown onion sauce. The bed of mashed potato and bright florets of broccoli on the side can’t be faulted, but the medallions of meat themselves were a little too chewy to be enjoyable. Though both dishes of the main course didn’t quite live up to the Parmesan starter that came before, things looked brighter when dessert was served. We chose to end the meal with zuccotto (`225). This traditional dessert is shaped like the cardinal’s skull cap that it’s named after – its artful sponge cake dome encloses dense lemon cream flavoured with orange rind. But our appreciative murmurs were directed more towards its accompaniment – a scoop of cocoa-intense, homemade dark-chocolate ice cream that melted to send streams of rich fudge swirling around the plate - Amrita Gupta

The newest outlet of the Kobe chain of restaurants presents a shimmering oasis of possibilities in the heart of Koramangala. The manicured garden patch out front makes for a welcoming façade, and it’s a good thing that the interiors are airy, as making your way to a table can get tricky. It’s like weaving through a minefield of spurting geysers and clouds of steam from all the sizzlers being deployed. But a few things about this establishment can be a bit misleading. For one thing, you can’t expect the marbled meat of beer-fed, sake-massaged, castrated Wagyu cattle at this steakhouse; there isn’t any genuine prime Kobe fare to be had. Although just the fact that the city stands to face an outright ban on beef makes even the most hardened buffalo meat seem kosher.Kobe’s T-bones and ribeye specials (`315 each) are definitely worth sinking those steak knives into, and the waiters are patient about jotting down your preferences (aided by a simple chart for picky eaters: “rare” means 10 minutes of cooking time, “medium” implies 15-20 minutes and “well-done” gives you a cut that’s been over the flame for 20-25 minutes). But we’d hesitate to wistfully conjure Anthony Bourdain’s steak au poivre with a well-done serving of Kobe’s pepper steak at hand.The adjuncts to the meal are all in place – the cosy high-walled booths, the rousing whiffs of searing meat in the air, the appetising spattering sounds, the gleaming cutlery, and neat piles of boiled veggies, greens and peas, not to forget the prompt service, but there is no hope of a glass of wine; they don’t serve any alcohol. But once you’ve reached the blackened base of your steak, prying off the fries fused to the tray, reaching for Tabasco to help with the timid sauce, you can’t help but think of all the better steaks that there are around.We never expected blood dribbling off our plates (for that we’d head to an establishment run by a gentleman named Manjit Singh), but it’s a sort of café culture about Kobe that may prove to be unnerving. We aren’t against wiener schnitzels being offered as part of the “tea time” menu, alongside burgers, rolls and sandwiches (`80-`170), while the options of satellites (grilled meat with mushrooms and fresh cream) and shashliks (skewered chunks served with rice; prices range from `275-`345) are entirely well-received. There are a few veg options here too, of paneer and mushroom sizzlers (`350 each) - Jaideep Sen

Terracotta is celebrating the curries of Lahore during this month-long food festival. There will be a selection of slow-cooked regional favourites on the special lunch menu, made with your choice of meat, poultry, seafood or vegetables. And on “BBQ Weekend Nights” the chefs will fire up the grill for patrons, who can pick from a range of meats and marinades

The Lucknowi restaurant now has a completely new menu. Chef Sanjay Tyagi has included specialty kababs from Rampur, Jaipur and Faridkot, and plans to make use of unusual ingredients like patthar ke phool, paan ki jad and khus ki jad in his creations. Signature picks from the new menu include dishes such as murg amras, jheenga multani, maans ke sooley and paneer aur anaar ki gilafi sheekh

The seating may be swanky and your coffee might come in a cup and saucer, but this new Mavalli Tiffin Room offshoot is still no-nonsense where it counts. It caters to the rushed lunch crowd seeking their trademark dosas, idlis or south Indian thalis without the trek to Lalbagh Road. You don’t want to wait for a menu here; there isn’t one. While the waiters briskly wipe down your share of a granite tabletop, read the specials off the blackboard. The popular pick seems to be the mini meal (`100). It comes with a serving of bisi bele bhath, rice, ragi roti, sambar, rasam, palya, raita, curd, pickle, mini papad rounds and a sweet dish. On your way out you can stock up the larder at home with pickles, ready-to-eat MTR goodies,namkeens, deep-fried savoury snacks, or sweets like the popular kaju kathli

This is one of the few places to grab a decent bite on your way to and from the airport. A Punjabi dhaba gone posh, there’s still the latest Hindi film music blaring, but the waiters are thankfully not dressed like bhangra dancers. Appetite-whetting aromas of fresh tandoori rotis waft from the open grill stations. Try the lachcha paranthas with the mildly spiced bhuna gosht

This is Shivajinagar food sanitised for the squeamish. On the fringe of the market, at a distance from the tide of humanity that threatens to sweep you along, sits the rather posh AJ International Hotel. However, not everyone knows that the hotel is the young sibling of the Taj Hotel in the heart of Shivajinagar. Which is a wonderful thing, really, given that the mutton biryani here is an exact replica of the one served at the mothership (the recipes are common, and the Taj chefs train the ones at AJ). However, unlike at the Taj, this is Shivajinagar biryani on real crockery with spoons and forks on the side. Be that as it may, it is best to abandon the cutlery and let your digits dig into the jeera rice-mutton-boti combo. It looks benign enough till you pop the first morsel in your mouth. It is when the chilli lights up your palate that you realise they mean business. The rice is small-grained and sticky and an apt vehicle to covey the masala into hungry mouths. The meat is fatty and flavourful and is brought in fresh from the market a whisper away

The food fest here begins with de rigueur pickled cucumber and kimchi. You may want to skip these as the courses start arriving at breathtaking speed not too soon after you’ve ordered. Soup is served scalding hot, and as you wait for the sweet corn chicken to cool a bit, the starters fly in. The crispy vegetarian Szechwan dry is near perfect, with the veggies having just the right crunch. They’re not on the menu, but ask for the eggplant and okra in hot bean sauce and assorted vegetables Hong Kong style. The staunchest of Chinamen would approve of the pan-fried greens. The sliced fish in devil’s sauce and chicken with mushroom in chilli oyster sauce are mellow. Dessert comes in the shape of a fried wonton with ice cream and fresh fruit on the side, but you will probably be too full to notice

Begin with the bruschetta trinagria, a jaunty snack of grilled bread layered with garlic and olive oil, seasoned and topped with basil, cheese and diced tomato on a salad leaf. All in all, it’s a rather pleasing start for the eyes and palate. The cottage cheese steak features slices of paneer grilled and sandwiched by vegetable concasse of three different flavours on a bed of parcel rice, while the lamb chops in red wine sauce is another enjoyable dish. It comes with a helping of sautéed vegetables and grilled potatoes

It’s easy to miss the discreet “Liquors not allowed” sign on the walls of this family restaurant, what with it being in bright magenta and adorned with painted umbrellas and busy Far-Eastern prints. But you don’t really miss the liquor, because both the Indian-ised Chinese and Thai menu (the wonderfully misspelt “bamboo shouts” and “bottom mushrooms”) and the food that Delicacy cooks up deserve your tee-total attention.To start with, you’ll be served complimentary fried vegetarian wontons with hot garlic sauce. Try the nam prik chicken strips – they’re coated in a pungent sweet-and-sour chilli sauce and basil leaves, and have crunch as well as kick.Another pleasant surprise is the tender and fatty roast pork. It comes in a piquant gravy with capsicum and spring onions, and goes well with the light, and far-from-greasy chicken fried rice with burnt garlic

The Ginseng kitchen is popular for its menu that spans south-east Asia – from Chinese, Japanese, Burmese and Thai to Malay and Indonesian cuisine, they’re known to have exclusive chefs for each culinary form. What the motley menu offers then, is a choice of soups, dim sums, curries, grilled or stir-fried dishes, teriyaki and teppanyaki dishes. We recommend the flavoured mince pork, pan-fried lamb (with mushroom, carrot and beans) and the triangular-shaped chicken mandarin dumplings. You could also try the lobsters and prawns cooked in oyster sauce

Choose to sit outside at this restaurant and watch the city sheathed in rain in the company of a beer and whiskey soda. As the puddles begin to grow to pools, sample the starters. To begin with, try the kheema vada – the texture of the finely pounded meat in this dish is enhanced considerably by the occasional burst of pepper, and though it is deep-fried, there is none of the glistening coat of oil you come to expect with such dishes. Next, the anjeer kabab: pan-fried medallions of finely chopped fig and cottage cheese. An excellent dish, this – the sweetness of the fruit is clouded in the salt of the cheese. For the Mysore chilli chicken and sarson ka saag, order an assortment of rotis. It is quite something to be able to taste just the slightest hint of jaggery in the Punjabi favourite, and the chicken, too, is spiced delicately – a rarity in most establishments that cater to the Indian palate

This pizzeria borrows song titles from Guns N’ Roses to Extreme for their Romano rock edition pizzas. Order “In the Flesh” even if there aren’t hardcore Floyd fans at the table: the 12-inch wood fire pizza is topped with prosciutto ham, roasted peppers, fresh tomato and garlic, salami, grilled eggplant and fresh mozzarella . It comes to the table with the cheese still bubbling, but looks good enough to make pizza burn inevitable. For dessert, go with the “nectar of gods” – it will suit both the cheesecake fiend and the chocoholic at the table just fine. Its creamy filling, dusted with chocolate powder, lies on a delicious chocolate base the consistency of molten cake batter

Eam Hie Yong is most at ease taking orders in Sanskrit. If only there was a way to order her spicy braised tofu in the ancient language. This academic-turned-chef and owner of Korean restaurant Soo Ra Sang cooks the way her mother taught her to: simple recipes, fresh ingredients and no unnecessary experimentation. There is a huge demand especially for the bibibap – a bowl of white rice topped with vegetables, sliced beef and an egg, with gochujang (chilli paste). But that’s second to the bul-go-ki, a Korean-style beef barbeque. It’s probably the Korean pre-toasted sesame oil that Hie Yong uses for added flavour that makes these dishes so popular. She also recommends her special squid pickle. Or her favourite, tofu stew

There’s nothing accommodating about the hordes of people here who only have one thing on their minds: assuaging their hunger pangs on their way to work, college,home or the police station (Banashankari Station is around the corner, so it’s a stopover for the cops). It only takes one bite of the vada to know all this early-bird stuff is worth the effort. Fried to just the right colour of golden brown, the vada tastes even more delicious after a dip in the coconut chutney which scores perfectly on the spice meter. This is best washed down with some heavenly, strong filter coffee, the south Indian steel tumbler and davarah way – though, this may take a little practice for the newbie to enjoy without the accompanying finger blisters, tongue burns and swear words

Suburbia positions itself squarely as a prototypical Goan establishment –indolent, languid and laid-back. Start with the yam crispies – though slightly bitter, they are redeemed by the splendidly fresh mint dip that accompanies them. Suburbia offers oddities like stroganoff on its menu, but you should stick resolutely to Goan fare chicken xacuti, mutton vindaloo, Goan wild rice and sannas. Of these, the xacuti is the star: freshly ground coconut weaving through a blend of dried red chillies, white poppy seeds and a sturdy bird

Located at the beginning of what is now called Food Street, the bakery offers snacks of all sorts – khara buns, vegetable puffs, potato buns, and that VB Bakery stalwart, the KBC. The fiendish popularity of this last item remains a mystery. For one, no one is really clear who came up with the idea of combining a khara bun with butter and Congress peanuts – that’s where the “K”, “B” and “C” come from. Does it work? Most certainly not; the flavours just don’t merge and the Congress sinks into the butter creating an odd and messy sludge that the flavour of the bun never manages to redeem. That, however, is the only anomaly at this place. The rest of the snacks are baked fresh in the morning and mostly consumed right at the establishment. The wait in the queue could be long –but it is well worth it

content.description: They might have been aiming for an Ice Hotel theme at this lounge bar, but there’s not much that’s wintry about Frost. The air conditioner keeps the ambient temperature just about pleasant, while, on the TV screens, voluptuous Bollywood divas are busy twisting-and-turning up the heat a notch. In fact, you’re more likely to feel as if you’ve ended up inside a swimming pool – whoever designed the interiors threw in a lot of curved pearlescent mosaic planes and decided that the lighting should change constantly. Venture a peek at the menu only when the room hasn’t turned a mood-altering shade of blue, which is also exceedingly taxing on the eyes. Between blues, the approximately 14 seconds of lurid pink and sunny yellow will reveal dubious ingredients on the menu like p-juice and m-juice. This, the staff explained to us, is just outright cooler than spelling pineapple and mango in full. We skipped over the drinks with foreshortened fruit names and asked for the barman’s special (Rs.250) instead. But first the barman had to be tracked down, and once he was located it became apparent that he doesn’t have much call to practice his cocktail-making skills, since the clientele at Frost seem to prefer their booze straight out of a tap (pint Rs.100; pitcher Rs.300). The bar also does a more-than-competent lime margarita (Rs.200); rotate the glass as you sip from it – the salted rim offsets the liberal pour of triple sec and tequila. Unless you’re ordering a beer, the snacks at this lounge bar come to the table much before the drinks do. Straying from the safe picks of peanut masala and French fries will ensure that everything you eat is pretty much Manchurian. We tried the chilli mushroom (Rs.75), which was deep-fried in the standard chilli seed-studded, HazMat orange masala, and the chicken winglets (Rs.120), which won us over with just their name. If you’re accompanied by an indignant aviation geek, you’ll learn that there’s nothing diminutive about winglets. They are in fact, “vertical extensions on the wing tip that have the important function of reducing aircraft drag”. The dish that goes by the same name can’t stake claims to cuteness either. The chicken has a serious spice kick and it’s stain-your-nails messy. If you would prefer to snack on something blander, ask for the paneer pakodas (Rs.75) – the mild cubes of cottage cheese are coated in a delightfully crunchy batter, and served with a sauce that’s sweeter than it is hot - Amrita Gupta

Ah, Mantri Square – that incontrovertible popper of Malleswaram’s mall cherry. And now, residence of Oval Bar, newest entrant to the city’s bar scene. On a bustling Friday evening, we dodged the crowded escalators and made our way up in a no-less crowded elevator to the third floor, where Oval Bar is situated. The bar, it turns out, is really just an enclosure; ergo, one isn’t given the normally expected comfort of having all external activity blocked out. This means that patrons cannot avoid the steady buzz of the mall and, at least on the day we visited, passers-by regularly peered over the fence at the bar, making us feel rather like zoo animals on display. Putting any resultant self-consciousness aside, we examined the menu and ordered ourselves a barman’s special cocktail (Rs.350) and a Long Island iced tea (Rs.400). The first had us intrigued when we saw that it came in an eye-catching bright green, topped with mint leaves, but its cloyingly sweet, bubblegum flavour evoked grimaces. The Long Island, that old failsafe choice for getting as pleasantly and efficiently tipsy as possible, didn’t disappoint: not too sugary or bitter, just bright and restorative. For our second round of drinks, we stopped appreciatively at the long list of whiskeys and single malts – selections in these sections include the Black Dog 18YO (Rs.500), Jura 16 (Rs.550) and the Dalmore 12YO (Rs.550). We chose, however, to go back to the cocktails and pick the Mai Tai (Rs.300), which they make here with sweet lime juice and an amalgam of white and dark rums. The fruity drink brought its trademark rum-spiked tropical goodness to the table and warmly ushered in some weekend wellbeing. For eats, we chose the mozzarella fritters (Rs.125), eagerly anticipating the promised pesto accompaniment; instead, the fritters first came with a gloopy cheese dip. After we requested them for the green stuff, we were given a similar cheesy concoction, but this time with bits of basil minced in. Fair enough, we thought, and proceeded: dipping one dip in another, we found, wasn’t too strange or excessive, and the fritters disappeared quickly. And while the spicy stuffed potatoes (Rs.125) are best avoided (we don’t need more soggy, bland tubers in our lives), the crispy fried chicken (Rs.150) is recommended. Oval Bar may have appeared as a new, strong player in the sparse list of Malleswaram watering holes, but the matter of whether it redeems the traffic-locked, cacophonous monstrosity that is Mantri Mall simply begs another question: how many malls is too many malls? - Neha Mujumdar

While the winged beetle employs bioluminescence to produce a warm, yellow glow, the nightclub which takes its name from the bug uses far more prosaic means to generate light – they have what appear to be scores of lamps that twinkle late into the night. Situated at the confluence of Lavelle and Walton roads, Fireflies divides its space into two levels – a terrace (which is where the wood-fired oven is situated) and an indoor seating area below. Ask for a table against the wall by the oven if you like the idea of being flanked by a chef tossing pizzas into the cubbyhole on one side and the shimmer of UB City on the other. The beverage menu here is large, with wines from South Africa, Argentina and Australia, as well as a splendid selection of local varieties. Ask for the electric iced tea and the chocolate martini. The first stays true to its name: electric blue in colour and electrifyingly perky in taste. The martini is redolent of Nesquik, which is not necessarily a bad thing. The food menu is just as robust as its booze counterpart. Try the margherita pizza, barbecued ribs and garlic prawns. These are served with a complimentary portion of sliced baguette and a lovely pesto sauce. If you are a sucker for traditional, thin-crust Italian pizza, Fireflies is an altar at which you may worship – the flour-dusted crust yields wonderfully, and the ingredients the chefs use are fresh and simple. The ribs and prawns too perform admirably: the first bathed in a tangy sauce and the second, buttery as scones

The owners have been rather unimaginative in choosing a name for this place, so called because it’s on the third floor of Manan Arcade. They might have turned instead to American indie cinema, in particular the winner of the 1995 Grand Jury Prize at Sundance, Welcome to the Dollhouse. Because a dollhouse is what this place most resembles, with little tables that are ankle high, and even a miniscule menu the size of a ticket-book. From the drinks section of this little book, ask for the melontini and the mai tai, and from the food section, try the fried crab sticks and cottage cheese fritters. The drinks are spot on: the watermelon and basil in the first mingle like they are lovers, and the mai tai displays a balance worthy of Nureyev. The food too, though not as grand, is more than competent: the cheese and crab are crusty on the outside and soft and flavourful on the inside. But is it worth hauling your tender frame past the debris of construction, insane one-way rules and the unsightly remnants of trees just to get a drink? Here’s what we think, and it might sound like we’re saying this under the influence – the only way to rail against the chaos in Bangalore is to go out and be part of it

A famous conversation from the 1953 romantic comedy How to Marry a Millionaire goes something like this: Loco Dempsey (Betty Grable): “I wouldn’t mind marrying a Vanderbilt.” Pola Debevoise (Marilyn Monroe): “Or Mister Cadillac.” Schatze Page (Lauren Bacall): “No such person. I checked.” Loco Dempsey: “Is there a Mister Texaco?” Similar thoughts about the usefulness of forging a matrimonial alliance with a man whose bank balance could buy a bank naturally pass through the mind at the ultra-posh Library Bar. Probably because everything about the place exudes the sweet smell of banknotes – right from the dark wood decor that is a throwback to the days of the regency, to the plush sofas, to the wine menu that is separate from the beverage list and is a book in itself (it includes wines which cost Rs.85,000 a bottle). The drinks are usually delivered on small silver trays in personal shakers which are mixed before the table in an elaborate ritual worthy of Veronica Lodge; the accompanying service is extremely attentive. Most of the other patrons may be guests staying at the Leela, which is all the more reason you should keep your un-spectacled eyes peeled, like Debevoise, for Mister Rich.

Noon Wines is also known as Scottish Pub is also known as Scotties, but that depends on where you’re sitting at this narrow, intimate pub on St Mark’s Road. If you’re indoors, listening to music and straining to see the wine, which smells so strongly of tomorrow’s hangover, you’re in Noon Wines. If you’re outdoors, not listening to music, but listening to the very potent wine as it makes its way down your gullet, you’re in Scotties. As you place your first order in Noon Wines, you will perhaps be informed by the waiter that they only serve three large wines per woman. This waiter is not to be confused with Eshwar, whom you must immediately ask for. Eshwar will then flash you a smile and get you pretty much whatever you want and however much you want of it. Even if you’re a woman. While you’re enjoying the friendly monster in your glass, ask Eshwar for a plate of chips masala: it’s not on the menu, but that only means it’s out winning an award somewhere

If you don’t expect anyone dressed like it’s 1999, chocolate martinis or even a playlist that brings back memories of a decade you weren’t born in (expect, instead Coldplay’s “Viva La Vida”) you could be in for a reasonably pleasant evening at Retro. Located above Ruchi Lunch Home, the family restaurant in Cambridge Layout, Retro could well be what a fellow writer termed “a family lounge bar”. It’s a place you could come to with the wife and mum to chat over a drink, or a gang of friends to cheer (or jeer) at Mahi’s men on the plasma TV over several drinks. Alternatively, you might bring a girl here on the eighth date when you’re broke and don’t really care about appearances anymore. The drinks are standard fare and the food is of the Hyderabadi chicken tikka variety, but again, since the menu makes no great promises, you don’t really have anything to complain about. As far as the setting goes, there’s ample space and you don’t feel like the strangers at the next table are going to overhear any of your embarrassing revelations

When you walk past the DJ at the entrance and find your way to the lounge seating, you’ll find that Vaayu is far from being a rambunctious celebration of aviation. In fact, there’s little to further the theme at all, save, perhaps, for the patch of open roof which affords one a view of the sky. One end of the lounge is fenced with bamboo plants, and next to it is a tranquil lotus pond with running water. If you sit near one of the many speakers (blaring everything from classic rock to hip hop to electronic music) you’ll have little hopes of making any conversation, a problem aided in no small measure by the fact that the smallest tables here seat you far enough to require shouting volumes if you want to be heard. Vaayu joins the growing list of venues that choose to abandon the banality of a “menu”; the super-attentive staff here will hand you a heavy volume that prefers the term “beverage dossier”. And it’s comprehensive enough to merit that title. It harbours an impressive array of selections across the liquor spectrum; their cocktails section alone spans several pages, with over ten options each for drinks based on vodka, rum, whiskey, tequila and gin. Of these, pick damn-the-weather: the gin and orange juice in this drink sunny up the table no matter how low the mercury levels are. Departing from tradition, they offer you a version of the silver Mercedes based on gin, as well as the standard vodka version. They also offer some generous happy hours: 1+1 till 8.30pm. For simple but addictive eats to accompany the drinks, pick the hummus and pita chips. This comes with both baked and fried varieties of chips which you can dip in a ramekin filled with a creamy-but-dull chickpea dip. The fiery reshmi kabab is also a good pick, arriving as it does with that all-too-rare entity, an accompanying salad that is flavourful enough to rise above being merely ghas-poos - Neha Mujumdar
